Statius's warhammer has a special attack , Smash , that consumes 35% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 25% and 125% of the user's max hit, while lowering the target's current Defence level by 75% on a successful hit . Defence level reductions do stack over multiple successful hits; each reduction is calculated from the current temporary level (so follow-up drains reduce fewer levels). Two successful special attacks thus reduce an opponent's Defence by a total of ~93%.

Statius's warhammer has a special attack , Smash , that consumes 35% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 25% and 125% of the user's max hit, while lowering the target's current Defence level by 30% on a hit other than zero (the hit has to deal damage - even if it is a successful hit but rolls a zero, it does not work). Defence level reductions do stack over multiple successful hits; each reduction is calculated from the current temporary level (so follow-up drains reduce fewer levels). Two successful special attacks thus reduce an opponent's Defence by a total of 51%.

Statius's warhammer has a special attack , Smash , that consumes 35% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 25% and 125% of the user's max hit, while lowering the target's current Defence level by 30% on a hit other than zero (the hit has to deal damage - even if it is a successful hit but rolls a zero, it does not work). Defence level reductions do stack over multiple successful hits; each reduction is calculated from the current temporary level (so follow-up drains reduce fewer levels). Two successful special attacks thus reduce an opponent's Defence by a total of 51%.

The Tonalztics of Ralos has a special attack , Division , costing 50% special attack energy. Division reduces the target's Defence level by 10% of its Magic level on a successful hit . This effect occurs for each individual hit, meaning a charged special attack can potentially reduce the target's defence two times (20% of Magic level) with a potential four time reduction if using two specials in a row (40% of Magic level) . This effect makes it uniquely useful for high-defence targets who have an accompanying high-magic level; Or for draining the defence of targets who are otherwise unreachable with standard methods (like a Dragon warhammer ) . An example being Zulrah : with her 300 Magic/Defence, Division can potentially drain up to 120 Defence (30 x 4) immediately and greatly increase accuracy for the duration of the fight. When used on NPCs, the defence reduction from a successful first hit will apply for the calculation of the second hit. However, this is not the case when used in PVP [1] . The special attack animation differs depending on whether the weapon is charged. A player performs Division with the uncharged weapon. A player performs Division with the charged weapon.

The toxic blowpipe has a special attack , Toxic Siphon , which increases accuracy by 100% and damage by 50%, while healing the user by half of the damage dealt (rounded down). This consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. Similar to the Saradomin godsword special attack, if the target dies from the special attack, it will still heal the player based on what they would have hit if the target had more Hitpoints; for example, if the hit was calculated to deal 20 damage and the target only has 4 Hitpoints, it will heal the player by 10 Hitpoints. For certain monsters, it heals based on the damage dealt before calculating damage reduction, such as Vorkath during its acid phase (where it will take 50% reduced damage), kurasks that have 100% damage resistance to most weaponry, or Akkha during his melee and ranged states which are 100% resistant to Ranged attacks.

The staff has a special attack , Power of Death , that halves all of the opponent's melee damage, consuming 100% of the player's special attack energy. Upon activating the special attack, a message will appear in the player's chatbox: " Spirits of deceased evildoers offer you their protection. " The effect lasts for one minute after using the special attack, but is immediately lost if players unequip the staff. In addition, the effect stacks with the PvP damage reduction effect of the Protect from Melee prayer .

The ursine chainmace has a special attack , Bear Down , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy and is only usable whilst charged. The special attack hits an enemy with doubled accuracy, and upon a successful hit , also deals 20 damage over 6 seconds, prevents running for 3.6 seconds (6 ticks), and reduces the target's Agility level by 20. The accuracy roll for Bear Down is based on the offensive bonuses of one's currently select style, which is rolled against an opponent's slash defences. [1]

Vesta's blighted longsword has a special attack , Feint , that consumes 25% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 20% and 120% of the user's max hit. The accuracy of this special attack is rolled against 25% of the opponent's defence .

Vesta's longsword has a special attack , Feint , that consumes 25% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 20% and 120% of the user's max hit, with the accuracy of this attack rolled against 25% of the opponent's defence . The accuracy roll of Feint is based on the attack bonus of the player's currently selected style, which is rolled against an opponent's stab defence. [1]

Vesta's longsword has a special attack , Feint , that consumes 25% of the player's special attack energy and deals between 20% and 120% of the user's max hit, with the accuracy of this attack rolled against 25% of the opponent's defence .

Vesta's spear has a special attack , Spear Wall , that consumes 50% special attack energy and performs an initial hit that deals up to 100% of the player's max hit. After 2 ticks (1.2 seconds), a second hit lands that deals between 50% and 75% of the damage inflicted by the first hit. In addition, the user becomes immune to melee attacks for 8 ticks (4.8 seconds). Upon a successful hit, the player's attack delay is reduced by 1 tick.

Vesta's spear has a special attack , Spear Wall , that consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy and damages up to 16 targets within 8 tiles surrounding the player (one if the player is outside a multicombat area ). In addition, the user becomes immune to melee attacks for 8 ticks (4.8 seconds).

The Voidwaker has a special attack , Disrupt , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. The special attack deals guaranteed Magic damage between 50-150% of the wielder's maximum melee hit. The special attack will provide Magic experience with the same formula as powered staves . The special attack is particularly useful due to its guaranteed medium to high damage. In PvP , it can be used for a consistent finishing blow and it pairs well with other high-damage special attack weapons such as the Armadyl or ancient godsword , dragon claws or granite maul due to its special attack cost. In PvM , it excels against opponents with high Defence and low-medium Hitpoints, such as Kalphite Queen , God Wars Dungeon bosses and Phosani's Nightmare , where dragon claws or other weapons would deal less damage on average and Defence reduction is less effective. As it deals Magic damage, it is less effective against opponents with a Magic damage resistance, such as players using Protect from Magic or Great Olm 's melee claw. Conversely, it deals full damage against the Corporeal Beast . In the Theatre of Blood , in the fight against Nylocas Vasilias , this special attack only deals damage against the magic (blue) form.

The Voidwaker (deadman) has a special attack , Disrupt , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. The special attack deals guaranteed Magic damage between 50-150% of the wielder's maximum melee hit. The special attack will provide Magic experience with the same formula as powered staves . The special attack is particularly useful due to its guaranteed medium to high damage. In PvP , it can be used for a consistent finishing blow and it pairs well with other high-damage special attack weapons such as the Armadyl or ancient godsword , dragon claws or granite maul due to its special attack cost. In PvM , it excels against opponents with high Defence and low-medium Hitpoints, such as Kalphite Queen , God Wars Dungeon bosses and Phosani's Nightmare , where dragon claws or other weapons would deal less damage on average and Defence reduction is less effective. As it deals Magic damage, it is less effective against opponents with a Magic damage resistance, such as players using Protect from Magic or Great Olm 's melee claw. Conversely, it deals full damage against the Corporeal Beast . In the Theatre of Blood , in the fight against Nylocas Vasilias , this special attack only deals damage against the magic (blue) form.

The Voidwaker has a special attack , Disrupt , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. The special attack deals guaranteed Magic damage between 50-150% of the wielder's maximum melee hit.

The volatile nightmare staff has a special attack , Immolate , that consumes 55% of the player's special attack energy to hit the target with 50% increased accuracy and deals a high amount of damage. The special attack does not consume runes. When calculating the max hit, Immolate acts like any other spell. The spell's max hit is calculated first and then rounded down (known in mathematics as "floor"). All magic damage gear, including the +15% from the staff is calculated separately. Because the staff has a magic damage bonus, the max hit seen in-game will always be higher than the spell's max hit. The max hit varies with visible Magic level according to the formula below. [1] The spell's max hit is limited to, at most, 58. This means that even though the max hit is based on the player's magic level, boosting above magic level 98 will not increase the max hit. It can be increased though by using additional magic damage gear including the Slayer helmet (i) when on a slayer task . Spell Max Hit = min ⁡ { ⌊ 5 8 * Magic Level 9 9 + 1 ⌋ , 5 8 } Staff Max Hit = ⌊ Spell Max Hit * 1 . 1 5 ⌋

The webweaver bow has a special attack , Swarm , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. The special attack hits an enemy four times in succession with doubled accuracy, each dealing up to 40%, rounded up, of the player's max hit. [1] Each hit also has a chance to inflict poison , starting at four damage.

The Zamorak godsword has a special attack , Ice Cleave , which consumes 50% of the player's special attack energy. It doubles the player's accuracy (slash or crush roll) and increases their max hit by 10%. In addition, it freezes the target in place for 19.2 seconds (32 ticks ); the same duration as Ice Barrage . The sword's special attack must produce a successful hit in order to have the freezing effect, and it rolls against opponent's slash defence. Protect from Melee only gives a damage reduction of 40% and does not affect the freeze. While its unique special attack may provide less utility than all other Godswords for the majority of situational uses, (e.g. it doesn't restore depleted stats, deplete opponent's stats, or deal any additional maximum damage relative to the other godswords), it is useful in numerous niche situations. It is very popular in the Castle Wars minigame when used to freeze flag-bearers, as such players generally wear equipment with high Magic defence bonus, such as black dragonhide , Karil's leathertop , and/or Armadyl armour in order to more easily defend against enemy mages casting Ancient Magicks (or Snare / Entangle with the standard spellbook). The use of this common strategy of possessing high magic defence bonus equipment, coupled with the game's particular magic defence -determining mechanics (that ultimately benefit accounts with higher levels in magic than defence), reliably renders magic-based freezing methods consistently ineffective. The Zamorak godsword's melee-based special attack is often used to undermine this tactic. In the Wilderness , it can also be used to freeze an enemy in place in order to attack from a distance, escape, or provide a more diversified (and therefore reliable) freezing strategy for clans; a useful tactic in Single-way combat is logging out while standing under a recently frozen enemy, as they will not unfreeze in time to retaliate. The Zamorak godsword has also found use in player-vs-monster situations. It is a popular weapon when fighting the Muttadiles , as it can stop them long enough from going to the meat tree to heal. It can also be used during the Barrows minigame to freeze the melee-using brothers in place, particularly Dharok the Wretched . The special attack animation 's colours can be changed to gold, which costs 75 Last Man Standing points. Once unlocked, the gold trim can be toggled at Justine's stuff for the Last Shopper Standing whenever the player desires.

The Zamorakian hasta has a special attack , Shove , which it shares with the dragon and Zamorakian spear . It pushes an opponent back and stuns them for three seconds, consuming 25% of the player's special attack energy. The effects of this special are non-stackable, meaning that players cannot use the hasta's special attack on a target who is already stunned. In addition to this, players are given a one tick (0.6 seconds) period of immunity after a stun wears off in which they cannot be stunned again. In addition to this, as soon as the stun wears off, the stunned player is also granted a 5 tick (3.0 seconds) period of immunity against being bound in place by binding spells like Entangle or Ice Barrage . On non-Castle Wars worlds, players within Castle Wars are able to shove targets back-to-back using this special attack. [1] In addition, it cannot be used against large monsters, such as giants, because they are too big to push back. If a player tries this, a regular attack occurs and no special attack energy is consumed. A message appears in the chat box, reading, "That creature is too large to knock back!" A general way to tell if the hasta can use the "Shove" special attack is to determine how much space the target monster takes up. If it takes up more than one space, it cannot be shoved. For example, a player can shove an ice warrior , which takes up one space, but not an ice giant , which takes up four.

The Zamorakian spear has a special attack , Shove , which it shares with the dragon spear and Zamorakian hasta . It pushes an opponent back and stuns them for three seconds, consuming 25% of the player's special attack energy. The effects of this special are non-stackable, meaning that players cannot use the spear's special attack on a target who is already stunned. Stunned players are also given a one tick (0.6 seconds) period of immunity after a stun wears off in which they cannot be stunned again. In addition to this, as soon as the stun wears off, the stunned player is also granted a 5 tick (3.0 seconds) period of immunity against being bound in place by binding spells like Entangle or Ice Barrage . On non-Castle Wars worlds, players within Castle Wars are able to shove targets back-to-back using this special attack. [1] The special attack cannot be used against large monsters, such as giants , because they are too big to push back. If a player tries this, the special attack does not occur and no special attack energy is consumed. A message appears in the chat box, reading, "That creature is too large to knock back!" A general way to tell if the spear can use the "Shove" special attack is to determine how much space the target monster takes up. If it takes up more than one space, it cannot be shoved. For example, a player can shove an ice warrior , which takes up one space, but not an ice giant , which takes up four.

The Zaryte crossbow has a special attack , Evoke , which consumes 75% of the player's special attack energy. The special attack provides doubled accuracy on the next shot, and guarantees the special effect of any enchanted bolts used, provided that the player lands a successful hit on the target. Enchanted ruby bolts are the most popular bolts to use with Evoke in most boss encounters, as successful hits can guarantee that 110 damage is dealt, assuming the enemy's health is high enough. Coupled with natural procs, this makes it a great option for speed-based Combat Achievement tasks. For prolonged encounters, wearing the lightbearer will make this combination even more powerful.
